{@b Darkness} skapar ett område som är mycket dolt. Karaktärer möter mörker utomhus på natten (även de flesta månbelysta nätter), inom gränserna för en obelyst fängelsehåla eller ett underjordiskt valv, eller i ett område med magiskt mörker.

entries.name: Blindsight
entries: En varelse med blindsight kan uppfatta sin omgivning utan att förlita sig på synen, inom en viss radie. Varelser utan ögon, som t.ex. oozes, och varelser med ekolokalisering eller förhöjda sinnen, som t.ex. fladdermöss och äkta drakar, har detta sinne.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: Många varelser i fantasyspelvärldar, särskilt de som lever under jorden, har mörkerseende. Inom ett specificerat område kan en varelse med mörkerseende se i svagt ljus som om det vore starkt ljus och i mörker som om det vore svagt ljus, så områden i mörker är bara lätt skymda när det gäller den varelsen. Varelsen kan dock inte urskilja färg i detta mörker, endast grå nyanser.

entries.name: Truesight
entries: En varelse med truesight kan, inom ett visst avstånd, se i normalt och magiskt mörker, se {@condition invisible} varelser och objekt, automatiskt upptäcka visuella illusioner och lyckas med räddningskast mot dem, och uppfattar den ursprungliga formen hos en formskiftare eller en varelse som förvandlats av magi. Dessutom kan varelsen se in i det eteriska planet.

entries.name: Actions in Combat
entries: När du gör din åtgärd på din tur kan du göra en av de åtgärder som presenteras här, en åtgärd som du har fått från din klass eller en specialfunktion, eller en åtgärd som du improviserar. Många monster har egna handlingsalternativ i sina statblock.

När du beskriver en handling som inte beskrivs någon annanstans i reglerna talar DM om för dig om handlingen är möjlig och vilken typ av rulle du behöver göra, om någon, för att avgöra om du lyckas eller misslyckas.

entries.name: Cover
entries: Walls, trees, creatures, and other obstacles can provide cover during combat, making a target more difficult to harm. A target can benefit from cover only when an attack or other effect originates on the opposite side of the cover.

There are three degrees of cover. If a target is behind multiple sources of cover, only the most protective degree of cover applies; the degrees aren't added together. For example, if a target is behind a creature that gives half cover and a tree trunk that gives three-quarters cover, the target has three-quarters cover.

A target with {@b half cover} has a +2 bonus to AC and Dexterity saving throws. A target has half cover if an obstacle blocks at least half of its body. The obstacle might be a low wall, a large piece of furniture, a narrow tree trunk, or a creature, whether that creature is an enemy or a friend.

A target with {@b three-quarters} cover has a +5 bonus to AC and Dexterity saving throws. A target has three-quarters cover if about three-quarters of it is covered by an obstacle. The obstacle might be a portcullis, an arrow slit, or a thick tree trunk.

A target with {@b total cover} can't be targeted directly by an attack or a spell, although some spells can reach such a target by including it in an area of effect. A target has total cover if it is completely concealed by an obstacle.

entries.name: Damage and Healing
entries: Injury and the risk of death are constant companions of those who explore the worlds of D&D. The thrust of a sword, a well-placed arrow, or a blast of flame from a fireball spell all have the potential to damage, or even kill, the hardiest of creatures.

entries.name: Hit Points
entries: Hit points represent a combination of physical and mental durability, the will to live, and luck. Creatures with more hit points are more difficult to kill. Those with fewer hit points are more fragile.

A creature's current hit points (usually just called hit points) can be any number from the creature's hit point maximum down to 0. This number changes frequently as a creature takes damage or receives healing. Whenever a creature takes damage, that damage is subtracted from its hit points. The loss of hit points has no effect on a creature's capabilities until the creature drops to 0 hit points.

entries.name: Damage Rolls
entries: Each weapon, spell, and harmful monster ability specifies the damage it deals. You roll the damage die or dice, add any modifiers, and apply the damage to your target. Magic weapons, special abilities, and other factors can grant a bonus to damage.

When attacking with a {@b weapon}, you add your ability modifier—the same modifier used for the attack roll to the damage. A {@b spell} tells you which dice to roll for damage and whether to add any modifiers.

If a spell or other effect deals damage to {@b more than one target} at the same time, roll the damage once for all of them. For example, when a wizard casts fireball or a cleric casts flame strike, the spell's damage is rolled once for all creatures caught in the blast.

entries.name: Critical Hits
entries: When you score a critical hit, you get to roll extra dice for the attack's damage against the target. Roll all of the attack's damage dice twice and add them together. Then add any relevant modifiers as normal. To speed up play, you can roll all the damage dice at once.

For example, if you score a critical hit with a dagger, roll 2d4 for the damage, rather than 1d4, and then add your relevant ability modifier. If the attack involves other damage dice, such as from the rogue's Sneak Attack feature, you roll those dice twice as well.

entries.name: Damage Types
entries: Different attacks, damaging spells, and other harmful effects deal different types of damage. Damage types have no rules of their own, but other rules, such as damage resistance, rely on the types.
The damage types follow, with examples to help a DM assign a damage type to a new effect.

entries.name: Acid
entries: The corrosive spray of a black dragon's breath and the dissolving enzymes secreted by a black pudding deal acid damage.

entries.name: Bludgeoning
entries: Blunt force attacks—hammers, falling, constriction, and the like—deal bludgeoning damage.

entries.name: Cold
entries: The infernal chill radiating from an ice devil's spear and the frigid blast of a white dragon's breath deal cold damage.

entries.name: Fire
entries: Red dragons breathe fire, and many spells conjure flames to deal fire damage.

entries.name: Force
entries: Force is pure magical energy focused into a damaging form. Most effects that deal force damage are spells, including magic missile and spiritual weapon.

entries.name: Lightning
entries: A lightning bolt spell and a blue dragon's breath deal lightning damage.

entries.name: Necrotic
entries: Necrotic damage, dealt by certain undead and some spells, withers matter and even the soul.

entries.name: Piercing
entries: Puncturing and impaling attacks, including spears and monsters' bites, deal piercing damage.

entries.name: Poison
entries: Venomous stings and the toxic gas of a green dragon's breath deal poison damage.

entries.name: Psychic
entries: Mental abilities such as a mind flayer's psionic blast deal psychic damage.

entries.name: Radiant
entries: Radiant damage, dealt by a cleric's flame strike spell or an angel's smiting weapon, sears the flesh like fire and overloads the spirit with power.

entries.name: Slashing
entries: Swords, axes, and monsters' claws deal slashing damage.

entries.name: Thunder
entries: A concussive burst of sound, such as the effect of the thunderwave spell, deals thunder damage.

entries.name: Damage Resistance and Vulnerability
entries: Some creatures and objects are exceedingly difficult or unusually easy to hurt with certain types of damage.

If a creature or an object has {@b resistance} to a damage type, damage of that type is halved against it. If a creature or an object has {@b vulnerability} to a damage type, damage of that type is doubled against it.

Resistance and then vulnerability are applied after all other modifiers to damage. For example, a creature has resistance to bludgeoning damage and is hit by an attack that deals 25 bludgeoning damage. The creature is also within a magical aura that reduces all damage by 5. The 25 damage is first reduced by 5 and then halved, so the creature takes 10 damage.

Multiple instances of resistance or vulnerability that affect the same damage type count as only one instance. For example, if a creature has resistance to fire damage as well as resistance to all nonmagical damage, the damage of a nonmagical fire is reduced by half against the creature, not reduced by three-quarters.

entries.name: Describing the Effects of Damage
entries: Dungeon Masters describe hit point loss in different ways. When your current hit point total is half or more of your hit point maximum, you typically show no signs of injury. When you drop below half your hit point maximum, you show signs of wear, such as cuts and bruises. An attack that reduces you to 0 hit points strikes you directly, leaving a bleeding injury or other trauma, or it simply knocks you {@condition unconscious}.

entries.name: Healing
entries: Unless it results in death, damage isn't permanent. Even death is reversible through powerful magic. Rest can restore a creature's hit points (as explained in chapter 8), and magical methods such as a cure wounds spell or a potion of healing can remove damage in an instant.

When a creature receives healing of any kind, hit points regained are added to its current hit points. A creature's hit points can't exceed its hit point maximum, so any hit points regained in excess of this number are lost. For example, a druid grants a ranger 8 hit points of healing. If the ranger has 14 current hit points and has a hit point maximum of 20, the ranger regains 6 hit points from the druid, not 8.
A creature that has died can't regain hit points until magic such as the revivify spell has restored it to life.

entries.name: Dropping to 0 Hit Points
entries: When you drop to 0 hit points, you either die outright or fall {@condition unconscious}, as explained in the following sections.

entries.name: Instant Death
entries: Massive damage can kill you instantly. When damage reduces you to 0 hit points and there is damage remaining, you die if the remaining damage equals or exceeds your hit point maximum.

For example, a cleric with a maximum of 12 hit points currently has 6 hit points. If she takes 18 damage from an attack, she is reduced to 0 hit points, but 12 damage remains. Because the remaining damage equals her hit point maximum, the cleric dies.

entries.name: Falling Unconscious
entries: If damage reduces you to 0 hit points and fails to kill you, you fall {@condition unconscious} (see the appendix). This unconsciousness ends if you regain any hit points.

entries.name: Death Saving Throws
entries: Whenever you start your turn with 0 hit points, you must make a special saving throw, called a death saving throw, to determine whether you creep closer to death or hang onto life. Unlike other saving throws, this one isn't tied to any ability score. You are in the hands of fate now, aided only by spells and features that improve your chances of succeeding on a saving throw.

Roll a d20. If the roll is 10 or higher, you succeed. Otherwise, you fail. A success or failure has no effect by itself. On your third success, you become stable (see below). On your third failure, you die. The successes and failures don't need to be consecutive; keep track of both until you collect three of a kind. The number of both is reset to zero when you regain any hit points or become stable.

entries.name: Rolling 1 or 20
entries: When you make a death saving throw and roll a 1 on the d20, it counts as two failures. If you roll a 20 on the d20, you regain 1 hit point.

entries.name: Damage at 0 Hit Points
entries: If you take any damage while you have 0 hit points, you suffer a death saving throw failure. If the damage is from a critical hit, you suffer two failures instead. If the damage equals or exceeds your hit point maximum, you suffer instant death.

entries.name: Stabilizing a Creature
entries: The best way to save a creature with 0 hit points is to heal it. If healing is unavailable, the creature can at least be stabilized so that it isn't killed by a failed death saving throw.
You can use your action to administer first aid to an {@condition unconscious} creature and attempt to stabilize it, which requires a successful DC 10 Wisdom ({@skill Medicine}) check.

A stable creature doesn't make death saving throws, even though it has 0 hit points, but it does remain {@condition unconscious}. The creature stops being stable, and must start making death saving throws again, if it takes any damage. A stable creature that isn't healed regains 1 hit point after 1d4 hours.

entries.name: Monsters and Death
entries: Most DMs have a monster die the instant it drops to 0 hit points, rather than having it fall {@condition unconscious} and make death saving throws.
Mighty villains and special nonplayer characters are common exceptions; the DM might have them fall {@condition unconscious} and follow the same rules as player characters.

entries.name: Knocking a Creature Out
entries: Sometimes an attacker wants to incapacitate a foe, rather than deal a killing blow. When an attacker reduces a creature to 0 hit points with a melee attack, the attacker can knock the creature out. The attacker can make this choice the instant the damage is dealt. The creature falls {@condition unconscious} and is stable.

entries.name: Temporary Hit Points
entries: Some spells and special abilities confer temporary hit points to a creature. Temporary hit points aren't actual hit points; they are a buffer against damage, a pool of hit points that protect you from injury.

When you have temporary hit points and take damage, the temporary hit points are lost first, and any leftover damage carries over to your normal hit points. For example, if you have 5 temporary hit points and take 7 damage, you lose the temporary hit points and then take 2 damage.
Because temporary hit points are separate from your actual hit points, they can exceed your hit point maximum. A character can, therefore, be at full hit points and receive temporary hit points.

Healing can't restore temporary hit points, and they can't be added together. If you have temporary hit points and receive more of them, you decide whether to keep the ones you have or to gain the new ones. For example, if a spell grants you 12 temporary hit points when you already have 10, you can have 12 or 10, not 22.
If you have 0 hit points, receiving temporary hit points doesn't restore you to consciousness or stabilize you.
They can still absorb damage directed at you while you're in that state, but only true healing can save you.
Unless a feature that grants you temporary hit points has a duration, they last until they're depleted or you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Making an Attack
entries: Oavsett om du slår med ett närstridsvapen, skjuter med ett vapen på distans eller gör en attackrulle som en del av en besvärjelse, har en attack en enkel struktur.

items.name: 1. Choose a target
items.entry: Välj ett mål inom attackens räckvidd: en varelse, ett föremål eller en plats.

items.name: 2. Determine modifiers
items.entry: DM avgör om målet har täckning och om du har fördel eller nackdel mot målet. Dessutom kan trollformler, specialförmågor och andra effekter tillämpa straff eller bonusar på din anfallsrulle.

items.name: 3. Resolve the attack
items.entry: Du gör en anfallsrulle. Vid en träff gör du en skaderoll, om inte den specifika attacken har regler som anger något annat. Vissa attacker orsakar speciella effekter utöver eller i stället för skada.

entries: Om det någonsin finns någon tvekan om huruvida något du gör räknas som en attack är regeln enkel: om du gör en attackrulle så gör du en attack.

entries.name: Attack Rolls
entries: När du gör en attack avgör din attackkast om attacken träffar eller missar. För att göra en anfallsrulle kastar du en d20 och lägger till lämpliga modifieringsfaktorer. Om summan av kastet plus modifierare är lika med eller överstiger målets rustningsklass (AC) träffar attacken. En karaktärs AC bestäms vid karaktärsskapandet, medan ett monsters AC finns i dess statblock.

entries.name: Modifiers to the Roll
entries: När en karaktär gör en anfallsrulle är de två vanligaste modifieringarna till rullen en förmågemodifiering och karaktärens färdighetsbonus. När ett monster gör en attackrulle använder det den modifierare som anges i dess statblock.

entries.name: Ability Modifier
entries: För en attack med närstridsvapen används styrka och för en attack med distansvapen används fingerfärdighet. Vapen som har egenskapen finesse eller thrown bryter mot den här regeln.
Vissa trollformler kräver också en attackrulle. Den förmighetsmodifierare som används för en trollformelattack beror på trollkarlens trollformelförmåga, vilket förklaras i kapitel 10.

entries.name: Proficiency Bonus
entries: Du lägger till din färdighetsbonus till din attackrulle när du attackerar med ett vapen som du har färdighet i, liksom när du attackerar med en trollformel.

entries.name: Rolling 1 or 20
entries: Ibland välsignar eller förbannar ödet en deltagare, vilket gör att nybörjaren träffar och veteranen missar.
Om {@dice d20} kastet för en attack är 20, träffar attacken utan hänsyn till eventuella modifieringar eller målets AC. Detta kallas en kritisk träff, vilket förklaras senare i detta kapitel.
Om {@dice d20} kastet för en attack är en 1 missar attacken oavsett modifieringar eller målets AC.

entries.name: Unseen Attackers and Targets
entries: Krigare försöker ofta undkomma sina fienders uppmärksamhet genom att gömma sig, kasta {@spell invisibility}-besvärjelser eller gömma sig i mörkret.

När du attackerar ett mål som du inte kan se har du nackdel på attackkastet. Detta gäller oavsett om du gissar målets position eller om du siktar på en varelse som du kan höra men inte se. Om målet inte befinner sig på den plats du siktade på missar du automatiskt, men DM säger vanligtvis bara att attacken missade, inte om du gissade målets plats korrekt.
När en varelse inte kan se dig har du fördel på attackkast mot den.
Om du är dold - både osedd och ohörd - när du gör en attack, avslöjar du din position när attacken träffar eller missar.

entries.name: Ranged Attacks
entries: När du gör en distansattack avfyrar du en båge eller ett armborst, kastar en handyxa eller skickar på annat sätt projektiler för att slå en fiende på avstånd. Ett monster kan skjuta taggar från sin svans. Många trollformler innebär också att man gör en distansattack.

entries.name: Range
entries: Du kan göra distansattacker endast mot mål inom ett visst avstånd.
Om en distansattack, t.ex. en trollformel, har en enda räckvidd kan du inte attackera ett mål utanför denna räckvidd.

Vissa distansattacker, t.ex. attacker med långbåge eller kortbåge, har två räckvidder. Den mindre siffran är den normala räckvidden och den större siffran är den långa räckvidden. Din attackrulle har nackdel när ditt mål är utanför normal räckvidd, och du kan inte attackera ett mål utanför den långa räckvidden.

entries.name: Ranged Attacks in Close Combat
entries: Det är svårare att sikta på en distansattack när en fiende är bredvid dig. När du gör en distansattack med ett vapen, en trollformel eller på annat sätt har du nackdel på attackkastet om du befinner dig inom en halvmeter från en fientlig varelse som kan se dig och som inte kan se dig {@condition incapacitated}.

entries.name: Melee Attacks
entries: När det gäller närstrid kan du med en närstridsattack angripa en fiende inom din räckvidd. En närstridsattack använder vanligtvis ett handhållet vapen som ett svärd, en krigshammare eller en yxa. Ett typiskt monster gör en närstridsattack när det slår till med sina klor, horn, tänder, tentakler eller andra kroppsdelar. Några få trollformler innebär också att man gör en närstridsattack.

De flesta varelser har en räckvidd på 5 fot och kan därför attackera mål inom 5 fot när de gör en närstridsattack. Vissa varelser (vanligtvis de som är större än Medium) har närstridsattacker med en större räckvidd än 5 fot, vilket anges i deras beskrivningar.

Istället för att använda ett vapen för att göra en närstridsattack kan du använda en {@b unarmed strike}: ett slag, en spark, en huvudstöt eller ett liknande kraftfullt slag (som inte räknas som vapen). Vid en träff ger ett obeväpnat slag en slagskada som är lika med 1 + din styrka-modifierare. Du är skicklig på dina obeväpnade slag.

entries.name: Opportunity Attacks
entries: In a fight, everyone is constantly watching for enemies to drop their guard. You can rarely move heedlessly past your foes without putting yourself in danger; doing so provokes an opportunity attack.

You can make an opportunity attack when a hostile creature that you can see moves out of your reach. To make the opportunity attack, you use your reaction to make one melee attack against the provoking creature. The attack interrupts the provoking creature's movement, occurring right before the creature leaves your reach.

You can avoid provoking an opportunity attack by taking the {@action Disengage} action. You also don't provoke an opportunity attack when you teleport or when someone or something moves you without using your movement, action, or reaction. For example, you don't provoke an opportunity attack if an explosion hurls you out of a foe's reach or if gravity causes you to fall past an enemy.

entries.name: Two-Weapon Fighting
entries: When you take the {@action Attack} action and attack with a light melee weapon that you're holding in one hand, you can use a bonus action to attack with a different light melee weapon that you're holding in the other hand. You don't add your ability modifier to the damage of the bonus attack, unless that modifier is negative.
If either weapon has the thrown property, you can throw the weapon, instead of making a melee attack with it.

entries.name: Contests in Combat
entries: Battle often involves pitting your prowess against that of your foe. Such a challenge is represented by a contest. This section includes the most common contests that require an action in combat: grappling and shoving a creature. The DM can use these contests as models for improvising others.

entries.name: Grappling
entries: When you want to grab a creature or wrestle with it, you can use the {@action Attack} action to make a special melee attack, a grapple. If you're able to make multiple attacks with the {@action Attack} action, this attack replaces one of them. The target of your grapple must be no more than one size larger than you, and it must be within your reach.

Using at least one free hand, you try to seize the target by making a grapple check, a Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check contested by the target's Strength ({@skill Athletics}) or Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check (the target chooses the ability to use). You succeed automatically if the target is {@condition incapacitated}. If you succeed, you subject the target to the {@condition grappled} condition (see the appendix). The condition specifies the things that end it, and you can release the target whenever you like (no action required).

entries.name: Escaping a Grapple
entries: A {@condition grappled} creature can use its action to escape. To do so, it must succeed on a Strength ({@skill Athletics}) or Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check contested by your Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check.

entries.name: Moving a Grappled Target
entries: When you move, you can drag or carry the {@condition grappled} creature with you, but your speed is halved, unless the creature is two or more sizes smaller than you.

entries.name: Shoving a Creature
entries: Using the {@action Attack} action, you can make a special melee attack to shove a creature, either to knock it {@condition prone} or push it away from you. If you're able to make multiple attacks with the {@action Attack} action, this attack replaces one of them.

The target of your shove must be no more than one size larger than you, and it must be within your reach. You make a Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check contested by the target's Strength ({@skill Athletics}) or Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check (the target chooses the ability to use). You succeed automatically if the target is {@condition incapacitated}. If you succeed, you either knock the target {@condition prone} or push it 5 feet away from you.

entries.name: Mounted Combat
entries: A knight charging into battle on a warhorse, a wizard casting spells from the back of a griffon, or a cleric soaring through the sky on a pegasus all enjoy the benefits of speed and mobility that a mount can provide.
A willing creature that is at least one size larger than you and that has an appropriate anatomy can serve as a mount, using the following rules.

entries.name: Mounting and Dismounting
entries: Once during your move, you can mount a creature that is within 5 feet of you or dismount. Doing so costs an amount of movement equal to half your speed. For example, if your speed is 30 feet, you must spend 15 feet of movement to mount a horse. Therefore, you can't mount it if you don't have 15 feet of movement left or if your speed is 0.

If an effect moves your mount against its will while you're on it, you must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity saving throw or fall off the mount, landing {@condition prone} in a space within 5 feet of it. If you're knocked {@condition prone} while mounted, you must make the same saving throw.

If your mount is knocked {@condition prone}, you can use your reaction to dismount it as it falls and land on your feet. Otherwise, you are dismounted and fall {@condition prone} in a space within 5 feet it.

entries.name: Controlling a Mount
entries: While you're mounted, you have two options. You can either control the mount or allow it to act independently. Intelligent creatures, such as dragons, act independently.
You can control a mount only if it has been trained to accept a rider. Domesticated horses, donkeys, and similar creatures are assumed to have such training.

The initiative of a controlled mount changes to match yours when you mount it. It moves as you direct it, and it has only three action options: {@action Dash}, {@action Disengage}, and {@action Dodge}. A controlled mount can move and act even on the turn that you mount it.

An independent mount retains its place in the initiative order. Bearing a rider puts no restrictions on the actions the mount can take, and it moves and acts as it wishes. It might flee from combat, rush to attack and devour a badly injured foe, or otherwise act against your wishes.
In either case, if the mount provokes an opportunity attack while you're on it, the attacker can target you or the mount.

entries.name: Movement and Position
entries: I strid är karaktärer och monster i ständig rörelse och använder ofta rörelse och position för att få övertaget.
På din tur kan du förflytta dig ett avstånd som motsvarar din hastighet. Du kan använda så mycket eller så lite av din hastighet som du vill på din tur, enligt reglerna här.

Du kan röra dig genom att hoppa, klättra och simma. Dessa olika rörelseformer kan kombineras med promenader, eller så kan de utgöra hela din rörelse. Hur du än rör dig drar du av avståndet för varje del av din rörelse från din hastighet tills den är förbrukad eller tills du har rört dig färdigt.
I avsnittet "Särskilda typer av rörelser" i kapitel 8 ges detaljerna för hopp, klättring och simning.

entries.name: Breaking Up Your Move
entries: Du kan dela upp din rörelse på din tur och använda en del av din hastighet före och efter din handling. Om du till exempel har en hastighet på 30 fot kan du förflytta dig 10 fot, utföra din åtgärd och sedan förflytta dig 20 fot.

entries.name: Moving between Attacks
entries: Om du gör en handling som omfattar mer än en vapenattack kan du dela upp din rörelse ytterligare genom att röra dig mellan attackerna. Till exempel kan en kämpe som kan göra två attacker med funktionen Extra attack och som har en hastighet på 25 fot förflytta sig 10 fot, göra en attack, förflytta sig 15 fot och sedan attackera igen.

entries.name: Using Different Speeds
entries: Om du har mer än en hastighet, t.ex. gångfart och flygfart, kan du växla fram och tillbaka mellan hastigheterna under din rörelse. När du växlar subtraherar du den sträcka du redan har förflyttat dig från den nya hastigheten. Resultatet avgör hur mycket längre du kan förflytta dig. Om resultatet är 0 eller mindre kan du inte använda den nya hastigheten under den aktuella förflyttningen.

Om du till exempel har en hastighet på 30 och en flyghastighet på 60 eftersom en trollkarl har förtrollat dig med flyga, kan du flyga 20 fot, sedan gå 10 fot och sedan hoppa upp i luften för att flyga 30 fot till.

entries.name: Difficult Terrain
entries: Striderna äger sällan rum i kala rum eller på slätstrukna slätter.
Stenbelagda grottor, skogar med törnrosor, förrädiska trappor - en typisk strid innehåller svår terräng.
Varje fot i svår terräng kostar 1 extra fot. Denna regel gäller även om flera saker i ett utrymme räknas som svår terräng.
Låga möbler, bråte, undervegetation, branta trappor, snö och grunda myrar är exempel på svår terräng. En annan varelses utrymme, vare sig det är fientligt eller inte, räknas också som svår terräng.

entries.name: Being Prone
entries: Stridsdeltagare ligger ofta på marken, antingen för att de slås ner eller för att de kastar sig ner. I spelet är de {@condition prone}, ett tillstånd som beskrivs i bilagan.

Du kan sänka {@condition prone} utan att använda din hastighet. Att stå upp kräver mer ansträngning; att göra det kostar en mängd rörelse som är lika med halva din hastighet. Till exempel, om din hastighet är 30 fot måste du använda 15 fot rörelse för att stå upp. Du kan inte resa dig upp om du inte har tillräckligt med rörelse kvar eller om din hastighet är 0.

För att förflytta dig medan du är {@condition prone} måste du krypa eller använda magi som teleportering. Varje fot som du rör dig när du kryper kostar 1 extra fot. Att krypa 1 fot i {@quickref difficult terrain||3} kostar alltså 3 fot i rörelse.

entries.name: Moving around Other Creatures
entries: Du kan förflytta dig genom en icke-fientlig varelses utrymme. Däremot kan du röra dig genom en fientlig varelses utrymme endast om varelsen är minst två storlekar större eller mindre än du. Kom ihåg att en annan varelses utrymme är {@quickref difficult terrain||3} för dig.
Oavsett om en varelse är en vän eller en fiende kan du inte frivilligt avsluta ditt drag på dess plats.
Om du lämnar en fientlig varelses räckvidd under ditt drag, framkallar du en möjlighet till attack, vilket förklaras senare i kapitlet.

entries.name: Flying Movement
entries: Flygande varelser har många fördelar med rörlighet, men de måste också hantera risken att falla. Om en flygande varelse slås {@condition prone}, får sin hastighet reducerad till 0, eller på annat sätt berövas förmågan att röra sig, faller varelsen, såvida den inte har förmågan att sväva eller hålls uppe med hjälp av magi, såsom genom {@spell fly}-besvärjelsen.

entries.name: Creature Size
entries: Varje varelse tar upp olika mycket utrymme.
Tabellen Storlekskategorier visar hur mycket utrymme en varelse av en viss storlek kontrollerar i strid. Objekt använder ibland samma storlekskategorier.

entries.name: Space
entries: En varelses utrymme är det område i fot som den effektivt kontrollerar i strid, inte ett uttryck för dess fysiska dimensioner. En typisk mediumvarelse är till exempel inte 5 fot bred, men den kontrollerar ett så brett område. Om en Medium hobgoblin står i en 5 fot bred dörröppning kan andra varelser inte ta sig igenom om inte hobgoblinen låter dem göra det.

En varelses utrymme återspeglar också det område som den behöver för att kunna slåss effektivt. Av den anledningen finns det en gräns för hur många varelser som kan omge en annan varelse i strid. Om man utgår från Medium-stridande kan åtta varelser rymmas inom en radie på 5 fot runt en annan varelse.
Eftersom större varelser tar mer plats kan färre av dem omge en varelse.
Om fyra stora varelser trängs runt en medelstor eller mindre varelse finns det inte mycket plats för någon annan. Däremot kan så många som tjugo Medium-varelser omge en Gargantuan-varelse.

entries.name: Squeezing into a Smaller Space
entries: En varelse kan klämma sig igenom ett utrymme som är tillräckligt stort för en varelse som är en storlek mindre än den. Således kan en Large varelse klämma sig igenom en passage som bara är 1,5 meter bred. När en varelse klämmer sig igenom ett utrymme måste den spendera 1 extra fot för varje fot den rör sig där, och den har nackdel på attackkast och Dexterity räddningskast. Attackkast mot varelsen har fördel medan den befinner sig i det mindre utrymmet.

entries.name: Variant: Playing on a Grid
entries: Om du spelar ut en strid med hjälp av ett kvadratiskt rutnät och miniatyrer eller andra brickor ska du följa de här reglerna.

entries.name: Squares
entries: Varje ruta på rutnätet motsvarar 5 fot.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Istället för att röra dig fot för fot rör du dig ruta för ruta på rutnätet. Detta innebär att du använder din hastighet i segment på 5 fot. Detta är särskilt enkelt om du översätter din hastighet till rutor genom att dividera hastigheten med 5. En hastighet på 30 fot motsvarar till exempel en hastighet på 6 rutor.
Om du ofta använder ett rutnät kan du överväga att skriva din hastighet i rutor på karaktärsbladet.

entries.name: Entering a Square
entries: För att gå in på en ruta måste du ha minst en ruta kvar att röra dig på, även om rutan är diagonalt angränsande till den ruta du befinner dig på. (Regeln för diagonal rörelse offrar realism för att underlätta spelet. Dungeon Master's Guide ger vägledning om hur man använder ett mer realistiskt tillvägagångssätt).

Om en ruta kostar extra rörelse, vilket en ruta på {@quickref difficult terrain||3} gör, måste du ha tillräckligt med rörelse kvar för att betala för att gå in på den. Till exempel måste du ha minst 2 rutor rörelse kvar för att gå in på en ruta med {@quickref difficult terrain||3}.

entries.name: Corners
entries: Diagonal rörelse kan inte korsa hörnet av en mur, ett stort träd eller ett annat terrängelement som fyller dess utrymme.

entries.name: Ranges
entries: För att bestämma avståndet på ett rutnät mellan två saker - vare sig det är varelser eller föremål - börja räkna rutor från en ruta som gränsar till den ena av dem och sluta räkna i den andra rutan. Räkna enligt den kortaste vägen.

entries.name: The Order of Combat
entries: En typisk strid är en sammandrabbning mellan två sidor, ett virrvarr av vapenslag, finter, parader, fotarbete och trollkonster. Spelet organiserar stridens kaos i en cykel av rundor och turer. En runda motsvarar ungefär 6 sekunder i spelvärlden. Under en runda tar varje deltagare i en strid en tur. Turordningen bestäms i början av ett stridsmöte, när alla kastar initiativ. När alla har tagit en tur fortsätter striden till nästa runda om ingen av sidorna har besegrat den andra.

entries.name: Surprise
entries: Ett gäng äventyrare smyger sig på ett banditläger och hoppar upp ur träden för att attackera dem. En gelatinös kub glider nerför en fängelsehålor, obemärkt av äventyrarna tills kuben slukar en av dem. I dessa situationer vinner den ena sidan av striden överraskande över den andra.

DM bestämmer vem som kan bli överraskad. Om ingen av sidorna försöker vara smygande märker de automatiskt varandra. Annars jämför DM Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) kontrollerna för alla som gömmer sig med den passiva Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) poängsumman för varje varelse på den motsatta sidan. Varje karaktär eller monster som inte märker ett hot blir överraskad i början av mötet.

Om du blir överraskad kan du inte röra dig eller vidta en åtgärd under din första tur i striden, och du kan inte vidta en reaktion förrän den turens slut. En medlem i en grupp kan bli överraskad även om de andra medlemmarna inte blir överraskade.

entries.name: Initiative
entries: Initiativet bestämmer turordningen under striden. När striden börjar gör varje deltagare en Dexterity-kontroll för att bestämma sin plats i initiativordningen. DM gör en rulle för en hel grupp av identiska varelser, så varje medlem i gruppen agerar samtidigt.

DM rangordnar de stridande i ordning från den som har den högsta summan av Dexterity-kontroller till den som har den lägsta summan. Detta är den ordning (kallad initiativordningen) i vilken de agerar under varje runda. Initiativordningen förblir densamma från runda till runda.

Om det blir oavgjort bestämmer DM:n ordningen bland bundna DM-kontrollerade varelser, och spelarna bestämmer ordningen bland sina bundna karaktärer. DM kan bestämma ordningen om det är oavgjort mellan ett monster och en spelarfigur. Eventuellt kan DM låta de bundna karaktärerna och monstren kasta varsin d20 för att bestämma ordningen, där det högsta kastet går först.

entries.name: Your Turn
entries: På din tur kan du {@b move} gå en sträcka upp till din hastighet och {@b take one action}. Du bestämmer om du vill flytta först eller om du vill utföra din åtgärd först. Din hastighet - som ibland kallas din gånghastighet - antecknas på ditt karaktärsblad.
De vanligaste åtgärderna som du kan vidta beskrivs i avsnittet "Åtgärder i strid" senare i det här kapitlet. Många klassegenskaper och andra förmågor ger ytterligare alternativ för din handling.
I avsnittet "Rörelse och position" senare i det här kapitlet beskrivs reglerna för ditt drag.

Du kan avstå från att röra dig, utföra en handling eller göra något alls under din tur. Om du inte kan bestämma dig för vad du ska göra på din tur kan du överväga att ta en {@action Dodge} eller {@action Ready} handling, enligt beskrivningen i "Handlingar i strid".

entries.name: Bonus Actions
entries: Olika klassegenskaper, trollformler och andra förmågor gör att du kan göra en extra åtgärd på din tur som kallas bonusåtgärd. Funktionen Cunning Action, till exempel, gör att en skurk kan göra en bonusåtgärd. Du kan ta en bonushandling endast när en specialförmåga, trollformel eller annan egenskap i spelet anger att du kan göra något som en bonushandling. I annat fall har du ingen bonushandling att ta.
Du kan bara göra en bonusåtgärd under din tur, så du måste välja vilken bonusåtgärd du vill använda när du har mer än en tillgänglig.

Du väljer själv när du vill utföra en bonusåtgärd under din tur, om inte bonusåtgärdens tidpunkt är specificerad, och allt som berövar dig din förmåga att utföra åtgärder hindrar dig också från att utföra en bonusåtgärd.

entries.name: Other Activity on Your Turn
entries: Din tur kan innehålla en mängd olika finesser som varken kräver din handling eller ditt drag.
Du kan kommunicera på det sätt du kan, genom korta uttalanden och gester, medan du tar din tur.

Du kan också interagera med ett objekt eller en funktion i miljön gratis, antingen under ditt drag eller din handling. Du kan till exempel öppna en dörr under ditt drag när du går mot en fiende, eller du kan dra ditt vapen som en del av samma handling som du använder för att attackera.
Om du vill interagera med ett annat objekt måste du använda din åtgärd. Vissa magiska föremål och andra specialföremål kräver alltid en handling för att användas, vilket anges i deras beskrivningar.

DM kan kräva att du använder en handling för någon av dessa aktiviteter när den kräver särskild omsorg eller när den utgör ett ovanligt hinder. Till exempel kan DM rimligen förvänta sig att du använder en handling för att öppna en fastlåst dörr eller vrida på en vev för att sänka en dragbro.

entries.name: Interacting with Objects Around You
entries: Här är några exempel på vad du kan göra i samband med dina rörelser och åtgärder:

items: ta ut en dryck från din ryggsäck
ta en kula från ett bord
ta bort en ring från ditt finger
stoppa in lite mat i munnen
fiska upp några mynt ur din bältesväska
dricka all öl i en flaska
slå en spak eller en omkopplare
dra en ficklampa från en lampett
ta en bok från en hylla som du kan nå
dra upp huvan på din kappa över huvudet.
vrida en nyckel i ett lås
ge ett föremål till en annan karaktär

entries.name: Reactions
entries: Vissa speciella förmågor, trollformler och situationer gör att du kan göra en speciell handling som kallas reaktion. En reaktion är en omedelbar reaktion på en utlösare av något slag, som kan inträffa på din tur eller på någon annans tur. Opportunitetsattacken, som beskrivs senare i det här kapitlet, är den vanligaste typen av reaktion.
När du gör en reaktion kan du inte göra en ny reaktion förrän i början av din nästa tur. Om reaktionen avbryter en annan varelses tur kan den varelsen fortsätta sin tur direkt efter reaktionen.

entries.name: Underwater Combat
entries: When adventurers pursue sahuagin back to their undersea homes, fight off sharks in an ancient shipwreck, or find themselves in a flooded dungeon room, they must fight in a challenging environment. Underwater the following rules apply.

When making a {@b melee weapon attack}, a creature that doesn't have a swimming speed (either natural or granted by magic) has disadvantage on the attack roll unless the weapon is a dagger, javelin, shortsword, spear, or trident.

A {@b ranged weapon attack} automatically misses a target beyond the weapon's normal range. Even against a target within normal range, the attack roll has disadvantage unless the weapon is a crossbow, a net, or a weapon that is thrown like a javelin (including a spear, trident, or dart).
Creatures and objects that are fully immersed in water have resistance to fire damage.

entries.name: Climbing, Swimming, and Crawling
entries: Varje fot i rörelse kostar 1 extra fot (2 extra fot i {@quickref difficult terrain||3}) när du klättrar, simmar eller kryper. Du ignorerar den här extra kostnaden om du har en klättringshastighet och använder den för att klättra, eller en simningshastighet och använder den för att simma. Enligt DM:s val kräver klättring på en hal vertikal yta eller en yta med få handtag en lyckad styrka ({@skill Athletics}) kontroll. På samma sätt kan det krävas en lyckad styrkaskontroll ({@skill Athletics}) för att ta sig fram i grovt vatten.

entries.name: Difficult Terrain
entries: De reshastigheter som anges i tabellen Travel Pace förutsätter relativt enkel terräng: vägar, öppna slätter eller tydliga fängelsehålor. Men äventyrare möter ofta täta skogar, djupa träsk, ruiner fyllda med spillror, branta berg och isbelagd mark - allt detta anses vara svår terräng.
Du rör dig med halva hastigheten i svår terräng - att förflytta dig 1 fot i svår terräng kostar 2 fot i hastighet - så du kan bara täcka halva den normala sträckan på en minut, en timme eller en dag.

entries.name: Jumping
entries: Din styrka avgör hur långt du kan hoppa.

entries.name: Long Jump
entries: När du gör ett längdhopp täcker du ett antal fot upp till din styrkepoäng om du rör dig minst 10 fot till fots omedelbart före hoppet. När du gör ett stående längdhopp kan du bara hoppa halva denna sträcka. I båda fallen kostar varje fot som du klarar av i hoppet en fot i rörelse.

Den här regeln förutsätter att höjden på hoppet inte spelar någon roll, till exempel när du hoppar över en bäck eller klyfta. På DM:s val måste du lyckas med en DC 10 styrka ({@skill Athletics})-kontroll för att klara ett lågt hinder (inte högre än en fjärdedel av hoppets avstånd), till exempel en häck eller en låg vägg. I annat fall träffar du det.
När du landar i {@quickref difficult terrain||3} måste du lyckas med en DC 10 Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics})-kontroll för att landa på fötterna. Annars landar du i {@condition prone}.

entries.name: High Jump
entries: När du gör ett höghopp hoppar du upp i luften ett antal fot som är lika med 3 + din styrka-modifierare (minst 0 fot) om du rör dig minst 10 fot till fots omedelbart före hoppet. När du gör ett stående höghopp kan du bara hoppa hälften så långt. I vilket fall som helst kostar varje fot som du klarar av i hoppet en fot i rörelse. Under vissa omständigheter kan din DM tillåta dig att göra en styrkekontroll ({@skill Athletics}) för att hoppa högre än vad du normalt kan.
Du kan sträcka ut armarna halvt över dig själv under hoppet. Du kan alltså sträcka ut dina armar över dig ett avstånd som motsvarar hoppets höjd plus 1½ gånger din längd.

entries.name: Travel Pace
entries: När en grupp äventyrare reser kan de röra sig i normal, snabb eller långsam takt, vilket visas i tabellen Travel Pace. Tabellen anger hur långt gruppen kan röra sig under en tidsperiod och om tempot har någon effekt. Ett snabbt tempo gör karaktärerna mindre lyhörda, medan ett långsamt tempo gör det möjligt att smyga runt och att söka igenom ett område mer noggrant (se avsnittet "Aktivitet under resan" senare i det här kapitlet för mer information).

entries.name: Forced March
entries: I tabellen Resetempo antas att personerna reser 8 timmar per dag. De kan fortsätta över den gränsen, med en risk på {@condition exhaustion}.

För varje ytterligare timme som går utöver 8 timmar, täcker karaktärerna den sträcka som anges i kolumnen Timme för deras tempo, och varje karaktär måste göra ett räddningskast i konstitutionen i slutet av timmen. DC är 10 + 1 för varje timme efter 8 timmar. Vid ett misslyckat räddningskast drabbas karaktären av en nivå av {@condition exhaustion} (se bilagan).

entries.name: Mounts and Vehicles
entries: Under korta perioder (upp till en timme) rör sig många djur mycket snabbare än människor. En beriden karaktär kan rida i galopp i ungefär en timme, vilket täcker dubbelt så lång sträcka som vanligt för en snabb takt. Om det finns färska hästar tillgängliga var 8 till 10 mil kan karaktärer täcka större avstånd i denna takt, men detta är mycket sällsynt utom i tätbefolkade områden.

Karaktärer i vagnar, vagnar eller andra landfordon väljer en takt som vanligt. Karaktärer i en vattenburen farkost är begränsade till farkostens hastighet (se kapitel 5), och de drabbas inte av straff för ett snabbt tempo eller får fördelar av ett långsamt tempo. Beroende på fartyget och besättningens storlek kan fartyg resa upp till 24 timmar per dag.

Vissa speciella hästar, t.ex. en pegasus eller griffon, eller speciella fordon, t.ex. en flygande matta, gör att du kan resa snabbare. Dungeon Master's Guide innehåller mer information om speciella resemetoder.

entries.name: Ability Checks
entries: An ability check is a test to see whether a character succeeds at a task that he or she has decided to attempt. The Player's Handbook includes examples of what each ability score is used for. The Ability Checks table summarizes that material for easy reference.

entries.name: Multiple Ability Checks
entries: Sometimes a character fails an ability check and wants to try again. In some cases, a character is free to do so; the only real cost is the time it takes. With enough attempts and enough time, a character should eventually succeed at the task. To speed things up, assume that a character spending ten times the normal amount of time needed to complete a task automatically succeeds at that task. However, no amount of repeating the check allows a character to turn an impossible task into a successful one.

In other cases, failing an ability check makes it impossible to make the same check to do the same thing again. For example, a rogue might try to trick a town guard into thinking the adventurers are undercover agents of the king. If the rogue loses a contest of Charisma ({@skill Deception}) against the guard's Wisdom ({@skill Insight}), the same lie told again won't work. The characters can come up with a different way to get past the guard or try the check again against another guard at a different gate. But you might decide that the initial failure makes those checks more difficult to pull off.

entries.caption: Ability Checks
rows: Smash down a door, move a boulder, use a spike to wedge a door shut
Sneak past a guard, walk along a narrow ledge, wriggle free from chains
Endure a marathon, grasp hot metal without flinching, win a drinking contest
Recall a bit of lore, recognize a clue's significance, decode an encrypted message
Spot a hidden creature, sense that someone is lying
Persuade a creature to do something, cow a crowd, lie to someone convincingly

entries.name: Contests
entries: A contest is a kind of ability check that matches two creatures against each other. Use a contest if a character attempts something that either directly foils or is directly opposed by another creature's efforts. In a contest, the ability checks are compared to each other, rather than to a target number.

When you call for a contest, you pick the ability that each side must use, deciding whether both sides use the same ability or whether different abilities should counter each other. For example, when a creature tries to hide, it engages in a contest of Dexterity against Wisdom. But if two creatures arm wrestle, or if one creature is holding a door closed against another's attempt to push it open, both use Strength.

entries.name: Intelligence Check vs. Wisdom Check
entries: If you have trouble deciding whether to call for an Intelligence or a Wisdom check to determine whether a character notices something, think of it in terms of what a very high or low score in those two abilities might mean.

A character with a high Wisdom but low Intelligence is aware of the surroundings but is bad at interpreting what things mean. The character might spot that one section of a wall is clean and dusty compared to the others, but he or she wouldn't necessarily make the deduction that a secret door is there.

In contrast, a character with high Intelligence and low Wisdom is probably oblivious but clever. The character might not spot the clean section of wall but, if asked about it, could immediately deduce why it's clean.
Wisdom checks allow characters to perceive what is around them (the wall is clean here), while Intelligence checks answer why things are that way (there's probably a secret door).

entries.name: Exploration
entries: This section provides guidance for running exploration, especially travel, tracking, and visibility.

entries.name: Using a Map
entries: Whatever environment the adventurers are exploring, you can use a map to follow their progress as you relate the details of their travels. In a dungeon, tracking movement on a map lets you describe the branching passages, doors, chambers, and other features the adventurers encounter as they go, and gives the players the opportunity to choose their own path. Similarly, a wilderness map can show roads, rivers, terrain, and other features that might guide the characters on their travels-or lead them astray.

The Map Travel Pace table helps you track travel on maps of different scales. The table shows how much distance on a map the adventurers can cover on foot in minutes, hours, or days. The table uses the travel paces-slow, normal, and fast-described in the Player's Handbook. Characters moving at a normal pace can walk about 24 miles in a day.

entries.name: Special Travel Pace
entries: The rules on travel pace in the Player's Handbook assume that a group of travelers adopts a pace that, over time, is unaffected by the individual members' walking speeds. The difference between walking speeds can be significant during combat, but during an overland journey, the difference vanishes as travelers pause to catch their breath, the faster ones wait for the slower ones, and one traveler's quickness is matched by another traveler's endurance.

A character bestride a phantom steed, soaring through the air on a carpet of flying, or riding a sailboat or a steam-powered gnomish contraption doesn't travel at a normal rate, since the magic, engine, or wind doesn't tire the way a creature does and the air doesn't contain the types of obstructions found on land. When a creature is traveling with a flying speed or with a speed granted by magic, an engine, or a natural force (such as wind or a water current), translate that speed into travel rates using the following rules:

items: In 1 minute, you can move a number of feet equal to your speed times 10.
In 1 hour, you can move a number of miles equal to your speed divided by 10.
For daily travel, multiply your hourly rate of travel by the number of hours traveled (typically 8 hours).
For a fast pace, increase the rate of travel by one-third.
For a slow pace, multiply the rate by two-thirds.

entries: For example, a character under the effect of a wind walk spell gains a flying speed of 300 feet. In 1 minute, the character can move 3,000 feet at a normal pace, 4,000 feet at a fast pace, or 2,000 feet at a slow pace.
The character can also cover 20, 30, or 40 miles in an hour. The spell lasts for 8 hours, allowing the character to travel 160, 240, or 320 miles in a day.

Similarly, a phantom steed spell creates a magical mount with a speed of 100 feet that doesn't tire like a real horse. A character on a phantom steed can cover 1,000 feet in 1 minute at a normal pace, 1,333 feet at a fast pace, or 666 feet at a slow pace. In 1 hour, the character can travel 7, 10, or 13 miles.

entries.name: Visibility Outdoors
entries: When traveling outdoors, characters can see about 2 miles in any direction on a clear day, or until the point where trees, hills, or other obstructions block their view. Rain normally cuts maximum visibility down to 1 mile, and fog can cut it down to between 100 and 300 feet. On a clear day, the characters can see 40 miles if they are atop a mountain or a tall hill, or are otherwise able to look down on the area around them from a height.

entries.name: Noticing Other Creatures
entries: While exploring, characters might encounter other creatures. An important question in such a situation is who notices whom.

Indoors, whether the sides can see one another usually depends on the configuration of rooms and passageways. Vision might also be limited by light sources. Outdoor visibility can be hampered by terrain, weather, and time of day. Creatures can be more likely to hear one another before they see anything.

If neither side is being stealthy, creatures automatically notice each other once they are within sight or hearing range of one another. Otherwise, compare the Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) check results of the creatures in the group that is hiding with the passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) scores of the other group, as explained in the {@i Player's Handbook}.

entries.name: Tracking
entries: Adventurers sometimes choose their path by following the tracks of other creatures-or other creatures might track the adventurers! To track, one or more creatures must succeed on a Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check. You might require trackers to make a new check in any of the following circumstances:

items: They stop tracking and resume after finishing a short or long rest.
The trail crosses an obstacle, such as a river, that shows no tracks.
The weather conditions or terrain changes in a way that makes tracking harder.

entries: The DC for the check depends on how well the ground shows signs of a creature's passage. No roll is necessary in situations where the tracks are obvious. For example, no check is needed to track an army advancing along a muddy road. Spotting tracks on a bare stone floor is more challenging, unless the creature being tracked leaves a distinct trail. Additionally, the passage of time often makes tracks harder to follow. In a situation where there is no trail to follow, you can rule that tracking is impossible. The Tracking DCs table offers guidelines for setting the DC or, if you prefer, you can choose a DC based on your assessment of the difficulty. You can also grant advantage on the check if there's more than one set of tracks to follow, or disadvantage if the trail being followed passes through a well-trafficked area.

On a failed check, the character loses the trail but can attempt to find it again by making a careful search of the area. It takes 10 minutes to find a trail in a confined area such as a dungeon, or 1 hour outdoors.

entries.caption: Tracking DCs
rows: Each day since the creature passed
Creature left a trail such as blood

entries.name: Madness
entries: In a typical campaign, characters aren't driven mad by the horrors they face and the carnage they inflict day after day, but sometimes the stress of being an adventurer can be too much to bear. If your campaign has a strong horror theme, you might want to use madness as a way to reinforce that theme, emphasizing the extraordinarily horrific nature of the threats the adventurers face.

entries.name: Going Mad
entries: Various magical effects can inflict madness on an otherwise stable mind. Certain spells, such as {@spell contact other plane} and {@spell symbol}, can cause insanity, and you can use the madness rules here instead of the spell effects in the Player's Handbook. Diseases, poisons, and planar effects such as psychic wind or the howling winds of Pandemonium can all inflict madness. Some artifacts can also break the psyche of a character who uses or becomes attuned to them.

Resisting a madness-inducing effect usually requires a Wisdom or Charisma saving throw. If your game includes the {@variantrule New Ability Scores: Honor and Sanity||Sanity score} (see chapter 9, "Dungeon Master's Workshop"), a creature makes a Sanity saving throw instead.

entries.name: Madness Effects
entries: Madness can be short-term, long-term, or indefinite. Most relatively mundane effects impose short-term madness, which lasts for just a few minutes. More horrific effects or cumulative effects can result in long-term or indefinite madness.
A character afflicted with {@b short-term madness} is subjected to an effect from the Short-Term Madness table for {@dice 1d10} minutes.
A character afflicted with {@b long-term madness} is subjected to an effect from the Long-Term Madness table for {@dice 1d10 × 10} hours.
A character afflicted with {@b indefinite madness} gains a new character flaw from the Indefinite Madness table that lasts until cured.

entries.caption: Short-Term Madness
rows: The character retreats into his or her mind and becomes {@condition paralyzed}. The effect ends if the character takes any damage.
The character becomes {@condition incapacitated} and spends the duration screaming, laughing, or weeping.
The character becomes {@condition frightened} and must use his or her action and movement each round to flee from the source of the fear.
The character begins babbling and is incapable of normal speech or spellcasting.
The character must use his or her action each round to attack the nearest creature.
The character experiences vivid hallucinations and has disadvantage on ability checks.
The character does whatever anyone tells him or her to do that isn't obviously self-destructive.
The character experiences an overpowering urge to eat something strange such as dirt, slime, or offal.

entries.caption: Long-Term Madness
rows: The character feels compelled to repeat a specific activity over and over, such as washing hands, touching things, praying, or counting coins.
The character experiences vivid hallucinations and has disadvantage on ability checks.
The character suffers extreme paranoia. The character has disadvantage on Wisdom and Charisma checks.
The character regards something (usually the source of madness) with intense revulsion, as if affected by the antipathy effect of the {@spell antipathy/sympathy} spell.
The character experiences a powerful delusion. Choose a potion. The character imagines that he or she is under its effects.
The character becomes attached to a "lucky charm," such as a person or an object, and has disadvantage on attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws while more than 30 feet from it.
The character is {@condition blinded} (25%) or {@condition deafened} (75%).
The character experiences uncontrollable tremors or tics, which impose disadvantage on attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws that involve Strength or Dexterity.

The character suffers from partial amnesia. The character knows who he or she is and retains racial traits and class features, but doesn't recognize other people or remember anything that happened before the madness took effect.

Whenever the character takes damage, he or she must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or be affected as though he or she failed a saving throw against the {@spell confusion} spell. The confusion effect lasts for 1 minute.
The character loses the ability to speak.
The character falls {@condition unconscious}. No amount of jostling or damage can wake the character.

entries.caption: Indefinite Madness
rows: "I try to become more like someone else I know—adopting his or her style of dress, mannerisms, and name."
"I must bend the truth, exaggerate, or outright lie to be interesting to other people."
"Achieving my goal is the only thing of interest to me, and I'll ignore everything else to pursue it."
"I find it hard to care about anything that goes on around me."
"I don't like the way people judge me all the time."
"I am the smartest, wisest, strongest, fastest, and most beautiful person I know."
"I am convinced that powerful enemies are hunting me, and their agents are everywhere I go. I am sure they're watching me all the time."
"There's only one person I can trust. And only I can see this special friend."
"I can't take anything seriously. The more serious the situation, the funnier I find it."
"I've discovered that I really like killing people."

entries.name: Curing Madness
entries: A {@spell calm emotions} spell can suppress the effects of madness, while a {@spell lesser restoration} spell can rid a character of a short-term or long-term madness. Depending on the source of the madness, {@spell remove curse} or {@spell dispel evil and good||dispel evil} might also prove effective. A {@spell greater restoration} spell or more powerful magic is required to rid a character of indefinite madness.

entries.name: Objects
entries: When characters need to saw through ropes, shatter a window, or smash a vampire's coffin, the only hard and fast rule is this: given enough time and the right tools, characters can destroy any destructible object. Use common sense when determining a character's success at damaging an object. Can a fighter cut through a section of a stone wall with a sword? No, the sword is likely to break before the wall does.
For the purpose of these rules, an object is a discrete, inanimate item like a window, door, sword, book, table, chair, or stone, not a building or a vehicle that is composed of many other objects.

entries.name: Statistics for Objects
entries: When time is a factor, you can assign an Armor Class and hit points to a destructible object. You can also give it immunities, resistances, and vulnerabilities to specific types of damage.

entries.name: Armor Class
entries: An object's Armor Class is a measure of how difficult it is to deal damage to the object when striking it (because the object has no chance of dodging out of the way). The Object Armor Class table provides suggested AC values for various substances.

entries.name: Hit Points
entries: An object's hit points measure how much damage it can take before losing its structural integrity. Resilient objects have more hit points than fragile ones. Large objects also tend to have more hit points than small ones, unless breaking a small part of the object is just as effective as breaking the whole thing. The Object Hit Points table provides suggested hit points for fragile and resilient objects that are Large or smaller.

entries.name: Huge and Gargantuan Objects
entries: Normal weapons are of little use against many Huge and Gargantuan objects, such as a colossal statue, towering column of stone, or massive boulder. That said, one torch can burn a Huge tapestry, and an earthquake spell can reduce a colossus to rubble. You can track a Huge or Gargantuan object's hit points if you like, or you can simply decide how long the object can withstand whatever weapon or force is acting against it. If you track hit points for the object, divide it into Large or smaller sections, and track each section's hit points separately. Destroying one of those sections could ruin the entire object. For example, a Gargantuan statue of a human might topple over when one of its Large legs is reduced to 0 hit points.

entries.name: Objects and Damage Types
entries: Objects are immune to poison and psychic damage. You might decide that some damage types are more effective against a particular object or substance than others. For example, bludgeoning damage works well for smashing things but not for cutting through rope or leather. Paper or cloth objects might be vulnerable to fire and lightning damage. A pick can chip away stone but can't effectively cut down a tree. As always, use your best judgment.

entries.name: Damage Threshold
entries: Big objects such as castle walls often have extra resilience represented by a damage threshold. An object with a damage threshold has immunity to all damage unless it takes an amount of damage from a single attack or effect equal to or greater than its damage threshold, in which case it takes damage as normal. Any damage that fails to meet or exceed the object's damage threshold is considered superficial and doesn't reduce the object's hit points.

entries.name: Poisons
entries: Given their insidious and deadly nature, poisons are illegal in most societies but are a favorite tool among assassins, drow, and other evil creatures.
Poisons come in the following four types.

entries.name: Contact
entries: Contact poison can be smeared on an object and remains potent until it is touched or washed off. A creature that touches contact poison with exposed skin suffers its effects.

entries.name: Ingested
entries: A creature must swallow an entire dose of ingested poison to suffer its effects. You might decide that a partial dose has a reduced effect, such as allowing advantage on the saving throw or dealing only half damage on a failed save. The dose can be delivered in food or a liquid.

entries.name: Inhaled
entries: These poisons are powders or gases that take effect when inhaled. Blowing the powder or releasing the gas subjects creatures in a 5-foot cube to its effect. The resulting cloud dissipates immediately afterward. Holding one's breath is ineffective against inhaled poisons, as they affect nasal membranes, tear ducts, and other parts of the body.

entries.name: Injury
entries: Injury poison can be applied to weapons, ammunition, trap components, and other objects that deal piercing or slashing damage and remains potent until delivered through a wound or washed off. A creature that takes piercing or slashing damage from an object coated with the poison is exposed to its effects.

entries.name: Sample Poisons
entries: Each type of poison has its own debilitating effects.

entries.name: Purchasing Poison
entries: In some settings, strict laws prohibit the possession and use of poison, but a black-market dealer or unscrupulous apothecary might keep a hidden stash. Characters with criminal contacts might be able to acquire poison relatively easily. Other characters might have to make extensive inquiries and pay bribes before they track down the poison they seek.
The Poisons table gives suggested prices for single doses of various poisons.

entries.name: Crafting and Harvesting Poison
entries: During downtime between adventures, a character can use the crafting rules in the Player's Handbook to create basic poison if the character has proficiency with a {@item poisoner's kit|phb}. At your discretion, the character can craft other kinds of poison. Not all poison ingredients are available for purchase, and tracking down certain ingredients might form the basis of an entire adventure.

A character can instead attempt to harvest poison from a poisonous creature, such as a snake, wyvern, or carrion crawler. The creature must be incapacitated or dead, and the harvesting requires {@dice 1d6} minutes followed by a DC 20 Intelligence ({@skill Nature}) check. (Proficiency with the {@item poisoner's kit|phb} applies to this check if the character doesn't have proficiency in Nature.) On a successful check, the character harvests enough poison for a single dose. On a failed check, the character is unable to extract any poison. If the character fails the check by 5 or more, the character is subjected to the creature's poison.

entries.name: Social Interaction
entries: During a social interaction, the adventurers usually have a goal. They want to extract information, secure aid, win someone's trust, escape punishment, avoid combat, negotiate a treaty, or achieve whatever other objective led to the interaction in the first place. The creatures they interact with also have agendas.

Some DMs prefer to run a social interaction as a free-form roleplaying exercise, where dice rarely come into play. Other DMs prefer to resolve the outcome of an interaction by having characters make Charisma checks. Either approach works, and most games fall somewhere in between, balancing player skill(roleplaying and persuading) with character skill (reflected by ability checks).

entries.name: Resolving Interactions
entries: The {@i Player's Handbook} provides guidelines for balancing roleplaying and ability checks in a social interaction (see chapter 8, "Adventuring," in that book). This section adds to that material by providing a structured way to resolve a social interaction. Much of this structure will be invisible to your players in play and isn't meant to be a substitute for roleplaying.

entries.name: 1. Starting Attitude
entries: Choose the starting attitude of a creature the adventurers are interacting with: friendly, indifferent, or hostile.

A {@b friendly} creature wants to help the adventurers and wishes for them to succeed. For tasks or actions that require no particular risk, effort, or cost, friendly creatures usually help without question. If an element of personal risk is involved, a successful Charisma check might be required to convince a friendly creature to take that risk.

An {@b indifferent} creature might help or hinder the party, depending on what the creature sees as most beneficial. A creature's indifference doesn't necessarily make it standoffish or disinterested. Indifferent creatures might be polite and genial, surly and irritable, or anything in between. A successful Charisma check is necessary when the adventurers try to persuade an indifferent creature to do something.

A {@b hostile} creature opposes the adventurers and their goals but doesn't necessarily attack them on sight. For example, a condescending noble might wish to see a group of upstart adventurers fail so as to keep them from becoming rivals for the king's attention, thwarting them with slander and scheming rather than direct threats and violence. The adventurers need to succeed on one or more challenging Charisma checks to convince a hostile creature to do anything on their behalf. That said, a hostile creature might be so ill-disposed toward the party that no Charisma check can improve its attitude, in which case any attempt to sway it through diplomacy fails automatically.

entries.name: 2. Conversation
entries: Play out the conversation. Let the adventurers make their points, trying to frame their statements in terms that are meaningful to the creature they are interacting with.

entries.name: Changing Attitude
entries: The attitude of a creature might change over the course of a conversation. If the adventurers say or do the right things during an interaction (perhaps by touching on a creature's ideal, bond, or flaw), they can make a hostile creature temporarily indifferent, or make an indifferent creature temporarily friendly. Likewise, a gaffe, insult, or harmful deed might make a friendly creature temporarily indifferent or turn an indifferent creature hostile.

Whether the adventurers can shift a creature's attitude is up to you. You decide whether the adventurers have successfully couched their statements in terms that matter to the creature. Typically, a creature's attitude can't shift more than one step during a single interaction, whether temporarily or permanently.

entries.name: Determining Characteristics
entries: The adventurers don't necessarily enter into a social interaction with a full understanding of a creature's ideal, bond, or flaw. If they want to shift a creature's attitude by playing on these characteristics, they first need to determine what the creature cares about. They can guess, but doing so runs the risk of shifting the creature's attitude in the wrong direction if they guess badly.

After interacting with a creature long enough to get a sense of its personality traits and characteristics through conversation, an adventurer can attempt a Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check to uncover one of the creature's characteristics. You set the DC. A check that fails by 10 or more might misidentify a characteristic, so you should provide a false characteristic or invert one of the creature's existing characteristics. For example, if an old sage's flaw is that he is prejudiced against the uneducated, an adventurer who badly fails the check might be told that the sage enjoys personally seeing to the education of the downtrodden.

Given time, adventurers can also learn about a creature's characteristics from other sources, including its friends and allies, personal letters, and publicly told stories. Acquiring such information might be the basis of an entirely different set of social interactions.

entries.name: 3. Charisma Check
entries: When the adventurers get to the point of their request, demand, or suggestion-or if you decide the conversation has run its course-call for a Charisma check. Any character who has actively participated in the conversation can make the check. Depending on how the adventurers handled the conversation, the Persuasion, Deception, or Intimidation skill might apply to the check. The creature's current attitude determines the DC required to achieve a specific reaction, as shown in the Conversation Reaction table.

tables.caption: Conversation Reaction
rows: The creature does as asked without taking risks or making sacrifices.
The creature accepts a minor risk or sacrifice to do as asked.
The creature accepts a significant risk or sacrifice to do as asked.
The creature offers no help but does no harm.
The creature does as asked as long as no risks or sacrifices are involved.
The creature accepts a minor risk or sacrifice to do as asked.
The creature opposes the adventurers' actions and might take risks to do so.
The creature offers no help but does no harm.
The creature does as asked as long as no risks or sacrifices are involved.

entries.name: Aiding the Check
entries: Other characters who make substantial contributions to the conversation can help the character making the check. If a helping character says or does something that would influence the interaction in a positive way, the character making the Charisma check can do so with advantage. If the other character inadvertently says something counter productive or offensive, the character making the Charisma check has disadvantage on that check.

entries.name: Multiple Checks
entries: Certain situations might call for more than one check, particularly if the adventurers come into the interaction with multiple goals.

entries.name: 4. Repeat?
entries: Once a Charisma check has been made, further attempts to influence the target of the interaction might be fruitless or run the risk of upsetting or angering the subject creature, potentially shifting its attitude toward hostility. Use your best judgment. For example, if the party's rogue says something that pushes a noble's attitude toward the party from indifferent to hostile, another character might be able to diffuse the noble's hostility with clever roleplaying and a successful Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check.

entries.name: Roleplaying
entries: For some DMs, roleplaying comes naturally. If it doesn't come naturally for you, don't worry. The main thing is for you to have fun portraying your NPCs and monsters and to amuse your players in the process. You don't need to be a practiced thespian or comedian to create drama or humor. The key is to pay attention to the story elements and characterizations that make your players laugh or feel emotionally engaged and to incorporate those things into your roleplaying.

entries.name: Being the NPC
entries: Imagine how a character or monster you bring to life would react to the adventurers. Consider what it cares about. Does it have any ideals, flaws, or bonds? By working such things into your portrayal, you not only make the character or monster more believable, but you also enhance the sense that the adventurers are in a living world.

Strive for responses and actions that introduce twists into the game. For example, an old woman whose family was killed at the hands of an evil wizard might regard the party's wizard with grave suspicion.

However you roleplay a character or monster, the classic advice for writers holds true: show, don't tell. For example, rather than describe an NPC as shallow and self-centered, have the individual act the way you would expect a shallow, self-centered person to behave. The NPC might have off-the-cuff answers for everything, an over-willingness to share personal anecdotes, and a desperate need to make himself or herself the subject of every conversation.

entries.name: Using Your Voice
entries: Most of what you say during a session will be at a consistent level. For dramatic effect, be ready to shout out a battle cry or speak in a conspiratorial whisper.

Also, characters and monsters with distinctive voices are memorable. If you're not a natural mimic or actor, borrowing distinctive speech patterns from real life, the movies, or television is a good place to start. Practice different voices and impersonations of famous people, then use those voices to bring your NPCs to life.

Experiment with different speech patterns. For instance, a barmaid and a city magistrate probably use their words differently. Similarly, peasants could speak in earthy dialects, while rich folk talk in haughty drawls.
Let a pirate NPC say, "Arrrr, maties!" in your best Long John Silver voice. Let intelligent monsters unfamiliar with Common stumble along with awkward grammar.

Let drunkards and monsters mutter with slurred speech, while lizardfolk hiss their threats. In any interaction with multiple NPCs, make sure the adventurers remain the focus. Have the NPCs talk to them, not so much to each other. If possible, let one NPC do most of the talking, but if multiple NPCs need to talk, give them distinct voices so the players know who's who.

entries.name: Using Your Face and Arms
entries: Use your facial expressions to help show a character's emotions. Scowl, smile, grin, snarl, pout, cross your eyes-do whatever it takes to make the character or monster memorable to the players. When you combine facial expressions with an unusual voice, a character truly comes to life.

Though you don't need to stand up out of your chair, you can use your arms to bring even more life to an NPC. A noble could chop the air with one hand while speaking in a deadpan monotone, while an archmage might express her displeasure by silently rolling her eyes and massaging her temples with her fingers.

entries.name: Engaging the Players
entries: Some players enjoy roleplaying and interaction more than others.
